posts.name: Carlos
posts.cooked:
I usually write stuff like $f(hat(beta))$ but would like to keep the parentheses as in $f(beta)$:

A workaround is $f"("hat(beta))$ but I noticed that it introduces undesirable spacing where math.ops are involved:

How can I get normal height parenthesis while avoiding the extra spacing, and perhaps in a more elegant way?

Thanks!
posts.raw:
I usually write stuff like `$f(hat(beta))$` but would like to keep the parentheses as in `$f(beta)$`:

![image|224x88, 50%](upload://xuabYwLNxCxeVNuwOd32XFLGTHj.png)

A workaround is `$f"("hat(beta))$` but I noticed that it introduces undesirable spacing where math.ops are involved:

![image|260x88, 50%](upload://ivTWVolc4PcoAhQHBbRG1p12Zyy.png)

How can I get normal height parenthesis while avoiding the extra spacing, and perhaps in a more elegant way?

Thanks!

posts.name: Max
posts.cooked: I think you can use paren.l and paren.r for that, as in $cos paren.l accent(beta, hat) paren.r cos(beta)$, which looks normal to me
posts.raw: I think you can use `paren.l` and `paren.r` for that, as in `$cos paren.l accent(beta, hat) paren.r cos(beta)$`, which looks normal to me

posts.name: Max
posts.cooked: You can also probably set size on lr to a contextual 0% + text.size if you want to override all lr delimiters not to scale in some places.
posts.raw: You can also probably set `size` on [lr](https://typst.app/docs/reference/math/lr#functions-lr-size) to a contextual `0% + text.size` if you want to override all lr delimiters not to scale in some places.

posts.cooked:
You should escape opening or both parentheses:

$f(hat(beta)) f\(hat(beta)) f(beta)$

$cos(hat(beta)) cos\(hat(beta)) cos(beta)$

posts.raw:
You should escape opening or both parentheses:

```typ
$f(hat(beta)) f\(hat(beta)) f(beta)$

$cos(hat(beta)) cos\(hat(beta)) cos(beta)$
```

![image|275x124, 75%](upload://rckNJudBDPCUqs6JvAPGSm6bxxi.png)

https://github.com/typst/typst/issues/6158

That seems like a good option too, that you can apply to an equation or part of it if you don’t want to write escapes. I think size 0% works without context?

#let nolr(it) = {
  set math.lr(size: 0%)
  it
}
